title: 108_hr2076
content: The Act titled "Veterans' Memorial Preservation and Recognition Act of 2003" establishes criminal penalties for the destruction of veterans' memorials. The Act "Veterans' Memorial Preservation and Recognition Act of 2003" establishes penalties for damaging or destroying veterans' memorials on public property, including fines, imprisonment up to 10 years, or both. The offense applies if the defendant travels in interstate or foreign commerce or uses mail or an instrumentality of interstate or foreign commerce. The Act "Veterans' Memorial Preservation and Recognition Act of 2003" imposes penalties for damaging veterans' memorials on federal property. It also allows for highway signs relating to veterans cemeteries and grants to repair veterans memorials. The Act "Veterans' Memorial Preservation and Recognition Act of 2003" allows for grants to repair covered memorials, with the Secretary able to provide up to 50% of the repair costs, and recipients required to cover the remaining costs. The Act allows grants for repairing covered memorials, with recipients using funds solely for repair purposes and adhering to set standards and guidelines. The Secretary may impose additional terms and conditions for grants. The Act authorizes grants for repairing covered memorials, with the Secretary defining terms like 'qualified organization' and 'covered memorial'. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2004-2008 for grant purposes. The Act authorizes grants for repairing covered memorials, with funds remaining available until expended. Unused grant funds must be returned to the United States if not utilized within three years. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in title 38, United States Code.
